an3.99:4.1: “Jute canvas is ugly, unpleasant to touch, and worthless whether it’s new, worn in, or worn out.
an3.99:4.4: They use worn out jute canvas for scrubbing pots, or else they just throw it away on the rubbish heap.
an3.99:5.1: In the same way, if a junior mendicant is unethical, of bad character,
an3.99:5.2: this is how they’re ugly, I say.
an3.99:5.3: That person is just as ugly as jute canvas.
an3.99:5.4: If you frequent, accompany, and attend to that person, following their example, it’ll be for your lasting harm and suffering.
an3.99:5.5: This is how they’re unpleasant to touch, I say.
an3.99:5.6: That person is just as unpleasant to touch as jute canvas.
an3.99:5.7: Any robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick that they receive are not very fruitful or beneficial for the donor.
an3.99:5.8: This is how they’re worthless, I say.
an3.99:5.9: That person is just as worthless as jute canvas.
an3.99:5.10: If a middle mendicant is unethical, of bad character, this is how they’re ugly, I say. …
an3.99:5.11: If a senior mendicant is unethical, of bad character, this is how they’re ugly, I say. …
an3.99:5.13: If you frequent, accompany, and attend to that person, following their example, it’ll be for your lasting harm and suffering.
an3.99:6.1: If such a senior mendicant speaks among the Saṅgha,
an3.99:6.3: ‘What’s an incompetent fool like you got to say? How on earth could you imagine you’ve got something worth saying!’
an3.99:6.4: That person becomes angry and upset, and blurts out things that make the Saṅgha throw them out, as if they were throwing jute canvas away on the rubbish heap.
an3.99:7.1: “Cloth from Kāsī is beautiful, pleasant to touch, and valuable whether it’s new, worn in, or worn out.
an3.99:7.4: They use worn out cloth from Kāsī for wrapping, or else they place it in a perfume casket.
an3.99:8.1: In the same way, if a junior mendicant is ethical, of good character, this is how they’re beautiful, I say.
an3.99:8.2: That person is just as beautiful as cloth from Kāsī.
an3.99:8.3: If you frequent, accompany, and attend to such a person, following their example, it will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.
an3.99:8.4: This is how they’re pleasant to touch, I say.
an3.99:8.5: That person is just as pleasant to touch as cloth from Kāsī.
an3.99:8.6: Any robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick that they receive are very fruitful and beneficial for the donor.
an3.99:8.7: This is how they’re valuable, I say.
an3.99:8.8: That person is just as valuable as cloth from Kāsī.
an3.99:8.9: If a middle mendicant is ethical, of good character, this is how they’re beautiful, I say. …
an3.99:8.10: If a senior mendicant is ethical, of good character, this is how they’re beautiful, I say. …
an3.99:9.1: If such a senior mendicant speaks in the midst of the Saṅgha,
an3.99:9.3: ‘Venerables, be quiet! The senior mendicant is speaking on the teaching and training.’
an3.99:9.4: So you should train like this:
an3.99:9.5: ‘We will be like cloth from Kāsī, not like jute canvas.’
